properties.name: Klondike Solitaire
properties.description:
This is a game example to show how to use an Object Stack extension to make card games with GDevelop.


The assets come from Kenney.nl

events.comment:
The Klondike Solitaire has several card stacks:
- 4 Fundations that must contain ace to king of the same suite to win the game
- 7 stacks that compose the Tableau, they are setup in the shape of a triangle
- the Stock that contains remaining cards
- the Deck that contains the cards picked from the stock (there is only one card in this example, but some variations have 3 cards)
- the Discard where the card from the Deck goes if another one is picked from the Stock.

Selection and Swap stacks only use is to move cards from one stack to another one in some situations.
Create one card of each and add it to the stock.
Allow to restart or bypass the animation.
Put cards from the stock outside of the screen to be sure they won't mess with mouse conditions.
They were backward at the end of the animation.

This way of setuping the board is overly complicated because of the animation.
There is a simple setup in SetupNoAnimation.

The animation starts from a game won state: every card is in the 4 fondations.
Cards are going to the reserve from one fondation at a time.

The card is flipped by the Flip3D behavior.
Sort the cards on z-order the other way around.
The initial z-order is: 1 + (PlayingCard::MaxValue() + 1) * Variable(fondationId) +  Card.PlayingCard::Value()
Adding: PlayingCard::MaxValue() - 2 * Card.PlayingCard::Value()
Make it: 1 + (PlayingCard::MaxValue() + 1) * Variable(fondationId) +  PlayingCard::MaxValue() - Card.PlayingCard::Value()
So now, the king is at the lowest position and the ace at the highest one.
Wait a bit more between 2 fondations.
Wait for the last card to reach its destination.

Z-Order the cards following the stock stack.
The cards were shuffled before the animation start.
Make the cards that will be in the diagonal face up.

Z-Order cards sent in the previous iterations according to tableaux.
Because the cards were on top of the stock, but they will under the following one in the tableaux.
Cards are placed diagonal by diagonal.
Wait for the last card to reach its destination.

A new card is revealed in 2 cases
- the stock is clicked
- the deck is empty because the card was dragged elsewhere

Deck and Stock must be picked back because the 1st condition can exclude Stock and the 2nd one can exclude Deck.

Roll the discard back into the stock.
Cards in the discard are in the opposite order as in the stock.
They are picked from the top of the discard to the top of the stock.
This operation opposes the order, so they are back in the right order.
Remove the previous card from the deck if it hasn't been used.
Pick a card.
No more card to pick

Several cards from tableaux can be dragged at once.
They are stuck together with an intermediate object (Glue)
because 2 objects of the same type can't be stick to one another.

The tableau is saved in the stack of Selection to know where to move cards from
when several cards are dragged at once.

The cardIsMoved variable is used to forget the cards that are picked by the condition
and continue with the card that has been dragged.
Only one card has been dragged and it's been selected by parent conditions.
It can simply be removed from whatever stack it was from.
When several cards are dragged at once, only one is selected by parent conditions.
The data from Selection are used to find which cards to move.

Align the cards of the tableau column where new cards have been dragged.
Because they were probably not dropped exactly where they should be.
See comments from the previous section.
Reveal the cards that are now on top of the tableau columns after the dragging.
Release cards when several ones were moved together.

Put all the card outside of the screen.
So, cards that are still in the stock at the end of the setup can't conflict with user inputs in any way.
The tableaux form a triangle like this: 1 card, 2 cards, 3 cards...
In a tableau, all cards face down unless...
...they are the last card in the column.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: VegeTato, D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ThreeDFlip
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Flip sprites with a 3D rotation effect.
description: Flip sprites with a 3D rotation effect.
Note that the X origin point must be at the center for the best results.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Flip a Sprite with a 3D effect.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: ThreeDFlip

eventsFunctions.description: Start a flipping animation on the object.
eventsFunctions.name: Flip

events.comment: The previous animation is not yet finished, flip the other way around starting from there.
Set the flipped property as if the previous animation has finished.
Start a new flipping animation.

eventsFunctions.description: Stops flipping the object.
eventsFunctions.name: StopFlip

eventsFunctions.description: Checks if a flipping animation is currently playing.
eventsFunctions.name: IsFlipping

eventsFunctions.description: Checks if the object has been flipped.
eventsFunctions.name: IsFlipped

eventsFunctions.description: Flips the object to one specific side.
eventsFunctions.name: FlipTo

events.comment:
When the object is flipping, the "is flipped" parameter is not yet set,
so it's value is the opposite of the animation goal.

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: Sticker
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Make objects follow the position and rotation of the object they are stuck to.
description: This extension can be useful to:
* Stick accessories to moving objects
* Animate a skeleton
* Delete an object with another one
An example allows to check it out ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://stick-objects)).

eventsFunctions.description: Define helper classes JavaScript code.
eventsFunctions.name: DefineHelperClasses

inlineCode: * Update the coordinates in the basisObject basis.
* It uses the basisObject coordinates from the previous frame.
* This way, the sticker can move relatively to it and still
// Save initial values to avoid calculus and rounding errors
* Copy the coordinates to use it the next frame.
* This method is also called by children to ensure
// If the behavior on the basis object has a different name,
// the objects will still follow their basis objects
// Follow parents 1st to avoid frame delays
object.setX(basisObject.getCenterXInScene() + object.getX() - object.getCenterXInScene() + deltaX * Math.cos(angle) + deltaY * Math.sin(angle));
object.setY(basisObject.getCenterYInScene() + object.getY() - object.getCenterYInScene() - deltaX * Math.sin(angle) + deltaY * Math.cos(angle));
// Unproportional dimensions changes won't work as expected
// if the object angle is not null but nothing more can be done
// because there is no full affine transformation on objects.

eventsFunctions.description: Check if the object is stuck to another object.
eventsFunctions.name: IsStuck

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Stick the object to another. Use the action to stick the object, or unstick it later.
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: Sticker

inlineCode: // Set up the scene sticker objects list - if not done already.
// Register this object as a sticker.

eventsFunctions.description: Stick on another object.
eventsFunctions.name: Stick

inlineCode: // An object can stick to only one object.

eventsFunctions.description: Unstick from the object it was stuck to.
eventsFunctions.name: Unstick

propertyDescriptors.label: Destroy when the object it's stuck on is destroyed
propertyDescriptors.name: IsDestroyedWithParent

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: ObjectStack
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: An ordered list of objects and a shuffle action.
description: It provides:
* Actions to modify a stack of objects
* Conditions to access the objects of a stack
* A shuffle action
It can be helpful for:
* Card games
* Fair randomness (for instance, to create a stack of predetermined bonus and randomize the order they appear)
3 examples use it:
* a card system demonstration ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://card-system))
* a Klondike solitaire ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://klondike-solitaire))
* a Zuma-like ([open the project online](https://editor.gdevelop.io/?project=example://smoothy))

eventsFunctions.description: Define helper classes JavaScript code.
eventsFunctions.name: DefineHelperClasses

eventsFunctionsExtensions.author: D8H
eventsFunctionsExtensions.name: CancellableDraggable
eventsFunctionsExtensions.shortDescription: Allow to cancel the drag of an object (having the Draggable behavior) and return it smoothly to its previous position.
description: Add this behavior on an object with the Draggable behavior and the Tween behavior.
Use then the action to cancel the drag, and the behavior will smoothly animate the object back to its original position, using a tween animation.

eventsBasedBehaviors.description: Allow to cancel the drag of an object and make it smoothly return to its original position (with a tween).
eventsBasedBehaviors.name: CancellableDraggable

events.comment: Save the object position to be able to revert the dragging.
Enable back the Draggable behavior when the object comes back to its position before it was dragged.

eventsFunctions.description: Cancel last drag.
eventsFunctions.name: CancelLastDragging
eventsFunctions.sentence: Cancel last dragging of _PARAM0_ in _PARAM2_ ms with easing _PARAM3_

eventsFunctions.description: Cancel last drag.
eventsFunctions.name: CancelLastDraggingS
eventsFunctions.sentence: Cancel last dragging of _PARAM0_  with easing _PARAM3_ in _PARAM2_ seconds

events.comment:
Move the object back to its position before it was dragged.
Disable the Draggable behavior to avoid it to be caught on the fly.

eventsFunctions.description: Dragging is cancelled, the object is returning to its original position.
eventsFunctions.name: DraggingIsCancelled
